snippet: High bodily levels of the trace elements nickel and selenium may be associated with reduced risk for pancreatic cancer, and high levels of arsenic, cadmium and lead may increase the risk.
abstract: Study published in journal Gut finds that high bodily levels of the trace elements nickel and selenium may be associated with reduced risk for pancreatic cancer and that high levels of arsenic, cadmium and lead may increase that risk; Nuria Malats of the Spanish National Cancer Research Center is study's lead author.
lead_paragraph: High bodily levels of the trace elements nickel and selenium may be associated with reduced risk for pancreatic cancer, and high levels of arsenic, cadmium and lead may increase the risk.

headline.seo: Trace Elements and Levels of Pancreatic Cancer Risk
headline.main: Patterns: Trace Elements and Pancreatic Cancer Risk
headline.print_headline: Patterns: Trace Elements and Pancreatic Cancer Risk
